definition: with great fanfare
big/huge/large/major/great/wide/deep/older (than)/oldest/eldest/greatly/very much/(dialect) father/father's elder or younger brother
see 大夫[dai4 fu5]
surname Zhang
to open up/to spread/sheet of paper/classifier for flat objects, sheet/classifier for votes
flag/variant of 旗[qi2]
banner/flag/(in Qing times) Manchu (cf. 八旗[Ba1 qi2])/administrative subdivision in inner Mongolia equivalent to 縣|县[xian4] county/CL:面[mian4]
drum/CL:通[tong4],面[mian4]/to drum/to strike/to rouse/to bulge/to swell
old variant of 鼓[gu3]

sentences.english: This does not have to be a massive undertaking.
sentences.chinese: 并不一定要大张旗鼓地进行这件事。

sentences.english: To this end, China should not unduly favor the judge-made law.
sentences.chinese: 为此，我国目前不宜大张旗鼓地主张法官造法。

sentences.english: Am I heading back in a big way?
sentences.chinese: 我算不算大张旗鼓地回来了？

sentences.english: EXAMPLE: The new product was introduced with a high-profiled advertising campaign.
sentences.chinese: 这种新产品通过一场大张旗鼓的广告攻势来推介。

definition: to muster large forces/to get a great number of people involved (in carrying out some task)
openly and without fear/brazenly
to spread one's voice wide (idiom); wide publicity
(of a person) honorable/not devious/(of a behavior) fair and aboveboard/without tricks/openly/(of a situation) out in the open
to take great pains/to go to a lot of trouble
to be secretive; to try to cover up (idiom)
high-sounding speech/bombast/high-profile
to go to war (idiom)/to make a big fuss over sth
overt/to make no secret (of one's presence)/grandiose/with great scope
wantonly/without restraint (of enemy or malefactor)/unbridled
just and honorable
to boost support or interest/to campaign/to promote
lit. to have sufficient reason to send troops (idiom)/to do something with good reason/to have just cause

definition: to make public/to disclose
